## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
Hey, I'm trying to set up Verus on a Linux system and I have a few questions. First, where is the `wallet.dat` file located?

**AI Assistant:**
The `wallet.dat` file is located at `~/.komodo/VRSC` on a Linux system for Verus. Do you have any other questions about setting up Verus on Linux?

**User:**
Yes, actually. What are the necessary files to install the Verus CLI wallet on a brand new Linux system?

**AI Assistant:**
The necessary files to install the Verus CLI wallet on a brand new Linux system are the latest wallet binary download and the Verus Bootstrap. You'll need both of those to get started.

**User:**
Okay, got it. I'm also setting up a new user on this system and I want to make sure they have root access. How can I verify that?

**AI Assistant:**
To verify that your new user has root (sudo) access, you can run a command that requires root privileges, such as `sudo ls -la /root`. If you have successfully set up sudo access, you should see a list of files and directories in the `/root` directory.

**User:**
What's the deal with the `fetch-params` command when installing the Verus CLI wallet? What does it do?

**AI Assistant:**
The `fetch-params` command is used to fetch parameters for the Verus CLI wallet, which can take some time to complete, especially on slower internet connections. It's just one of the steps you need to go through to get Verus up and running.

**User:**
And what about the Verus Bootstrap? Why do I need to download that?

**AI Assistant:**
Downloading the Verus Bootstrap significantly speeds up the synchronization of the blockchain from days to minutes. This is an optional step, but it can save a lot of time in the long run. Trust me, you'll want to do it!

Where is the `wallet.dat` file located on a Linux system for Verus?
The `wallet.dat` file is located at `~/.komodo/VRSC` on a Linux system for Verus.

# How do I install the Verus CLI (command line interface) wallet on a brand new (hosted) Linux system?Notice: Read it completely before use.#### Important General Information`wallet.dat` location on Linux: `~/.komodo/VRSC`#### Necessary files:Link 1: [Download latest Wallet](https://verus.io/wallet)
Link 2: [Download Verus Bootstrap](https://bootstrap.verus.io/)## Procedure:1. First make sure your system is up to date: 
 `sudo apt-get update && apt-get upgrade -y`2. I suggest not to use the root account. I you have not yet done, set up a new user
 `sudo adduser newusername`
 `sudo usermod -aG sudo newusername`
3. Switch to new username
 `su - newusername`
4. Test the your new user actually has root (SuDo) access, e.g.:
 `sudo ls -la /root`
 You should get some lines like this:
 `drwx------ 6 root root 4096 Jul 3 15:56`
5. Download & install the wallet binaries:
 `wget https://github.com/VerusCoin/VerusCoin/releases/download/v0.9.3/Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.9.3-amd64.tgz`
 The downloaded archive contains another archive and a signature text file, enabling the archive within to be verified (You'll need a running wallet to do that)
 Also: Verify the URL to the latest version from the [Download latest Wallet](https://verus.io/wallet) above.
 `tar -xvf Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.9.3-amd64.tgz`
 Now extract the wallet archive:
 `tar -xvf Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.9.3-amd64.tar.gz`
 Change directory to verus-cli
 `cd verus-cli`
 Fetch parameters, takes time, more on slow Internet connection
 `./fetch-params`
Creating the chaindata directory
 `cd ~`
 `mkdir -p .komodo/VRSC`
 `cd ~/.komodo/VRSC`
Download the block-chain bootstrap, this considerably speeds up synchronisation of the block-chain from days to minutes... (optional)
 `wget https://bootstrap.verus.io/VRSC-bootstrap.tar.gz`
 `tar -xvf VRSC-bootstrap.tar.gz`
 Install libraries for Verus
 `sudo apt-get install libcurl3
./raw_text_input_wiki/faq-lin01_install_linux_cli.md
What are the necessary files to install the Verus CLI wallet on a brand new Linux system?
The necessary files to install the Verus CLI wallet on a brand new Linux system are the latest wallet binary download and the Verus Bootstrap.

How can I verify that my new user has root (sudo) access after setting it up on a Linux system?

You can verify that your new user has root (sudo) access by running a command that requires root privileges, such as `sudo ls -la /root`. If you have successfully set up sudo access, you should see a list of files and directories in the `/root` directory.
